Scheme 1 The representation and electrocatalytic applications of homonuclear and heteronuclear dual-atom catalysts with adjacent, bridged, and separated configurations. Review Engineering of geometrical configurations in dual-atom catalysts for electrocatalytic applications Tao Zhang 1 Yifan Liu 1 Liang Xue Jingwen Sun Pan Xiong ⁎ Junwu Zhu Key Laboratory for Soft Chemistry and Functional Materials of Ministry Education, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, Jiangsu, China Key Laboratory for Soft Chemistry and Functional Materials of Ministry Education School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 Jiangsu China Key Laboratory for Soft Chemistry and Functional Materials of Ministry Education, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, Nanjing, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract The homonuclear and heteronuclear dual-atom catalysts were summarized with adjacent, bridged, and separated configurations, together with their representative electrocatalytic applications. Geometrical configurations play a crucial role in dual-atom catalysts (DACs) for electrocatalytic applications. Significant progress has been made to design DACs electrocatalysts with various geometrical configurations, but in-depth understanding the relationship between geometrical configurations and metal-metal interaction mechanisms for designing targeted DACs is still required. In this review, the recent progress in engineering of geometrical configurations of DACs is systematically summarized. Based on the polarity of geometrical configuration, DACs can be classified into two different types that are homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs. Furthermore, with regard to the geometrical configurations of the active sites, homonuclear DACs are identified into adjacent and bridged configurations, and heteronuclear DACs can be classified into adjacent, bridged, and separated configurations. Subsequently, metal-metal interactions in DACs with different geometrical configurations are introduced. Additionally, the applications of DACs in different electrocatalytic reactions are discussed, including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and other catalysis. Finally, the future challenges and perspectives for advancements in DACs are highlighted. This review aims to provide inspiration for the design of highly efficient DACs towards energy related applications. Keywords Dual-atom catalysts Geometrical configurations Homonuclear Heteronuclear Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction With the ever-increasing energy crisis and environmental contamination, significant efforts have been dedicated to the exploration and development of efficient energy conversion technologies [1–9]. Energy conversion based on various catalytic reactions is a promising strategy for efficiently converting energy through chemical bond transitions [10–18]. In recent years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have garnered significant attention due to their exceptional atomic utilization and fully exposed active sites. SACs are considered as highly promising materials for various electrochemical applications [19–23]. Despite the remarkable achievements made in the field of SACs, their activities in some multi-electron catalytic pathways are still unsatisfactory [24,25]. Currently, dual-atom catalysts (DACs) have received considerable attention as an extension of SACs to address certain limitations. In addition to inheriting all advantages of SACs, DACs offer more flexible active sites and higher metal atom loadings than SACs [26–28]. DACs are not simply a doubling of single atoms. They possess the potential to introduce a synergistic effect that can surpass the theoretical limits of SACs [29–31]. Based on the metal-bonding polarity, DACs can be classified into homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs (Fig. 1 ) [32–41]. For homonuclear precious metal DACs, Tian et al. [37] synthesized mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride loaded with Pt2 DACs using a wet chemical method. The same scheme was also adopted for the synthesis of transition metal iron diatoms, demonstrating the general applicability of the method for synthesizing diatomic catalysts. These dimers can also be synthesized using other methods for homonuclear non-precious metal catalysts. For example, Wang et al. [39] prepared electrocatalysts with diatomic iron sites (Fe2-N6-C DAC). N-doped carbon carriers were successfully synthesized using a template-assisted method under H2 pyrolysis conditions. In parallel with the development of homonuclear DACs, notable advancements have also been made in heteronuclear precious metal DACs. Zhang et al. [35] conducted an atomic layer deposition method for the preparation of Pt-Ru dimer catalysts, where Ru can be attached to Pt to selectively form dual-metal configurations. For heteronuclear precious/non-precious-based DAC catalysts, thermodynamic stabilization can both be effectively promoted. The introduction of noble metals facilitates the stripping of non-precious metals from nanoparticles to form stable DACs from individual metals. For example, Zhou and co-workers [42] introduced a novel chemical facilitator to induce the formation of dual-metal (Rh–Fe) interbond; the presence of iron hinders the formation of Rh nanoparticles, and the formation of Rh–Fe bonds facilitates the stripping of bonded iron atoms from the metal nanoparticles. For heteronuclear non-precious metal DACs, the d-electron rich nature of transition metal center allows for flexible modulation of the electron structure through d-band coordination. Zeng and co-workers [38] successfully prepared a high-density NiFe DACs by anchoring heteronuclear Ni and Fe atoms on N-doped graphene. By experimental characterization and theoretical analysis, orbital coupling between the Fe center and adjacent Ni atoms leads to a higher oxidation state of Fe and a weaker binding strength to the intermediate. These mentioned reports have demonstrated the existence of a wide range of geometrical configurations in both homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs. Understanding the relationship between geometrical configurations and metal-metal interaction mechanisms is crucial for targeted design of diatomic electrocatalysts. However, a latest and systematic summary of the effect of metal-metal interaction mechanisms on electrocatalytic performance in DACs is lacking. Meanwhile, DACs have a wide range of applications in electrocatalysis, including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and so on, and these electrocatalytic reactions are important in some energy storage and energy conversion. This requires a comprehensive review summarizing the electrocatalytic applications of DACs. This review aims to comprehensively summarize the development of DACs and discuss the relationship between geometrical configuration and mechanism of metal-metal interactions. Based on the bonding configurations, DACs can be classified into three types: (1) adjacent DACs, in which the metal atoms are directly coordinated; (2) bridged DACs, in which the metal atoms are connected by bridged atoms such as O, N, and S; (3) separated DACs, metal atoms atomically distanced in different planes. Furthermore, according to the similarity or difference of the two metal atoms in their configuration, DACs can be categorized as homonuclear DACs and heteronuclear DACs, as shown in Scheme 1 . Subsequently, the configurations and reaction mechanisms for homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs are explored separately, and the relationship between the corresponding configurations and the mechanism of metal-metal interactions are given by theoretical and experimental results. Finally, the challenges and outlook for DACs developments are summarized. 2 DACs configurations Based on whether the two adjacent metal atoms in the configuration are the same or not, DACs can be classified into homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs. Meanwhile, based on the geometrical configurations of the active sites, homonuclear DACs can be classified into adjacent and bridged configurations, and heteronuclear DACs can be classified into adjacent, bridged, and separated configurations. 2.1 Heteronuclear DACs 2.1.1 Adjacent configuration Compared with homonuclear DACs, heteronuclear DACs may potentially exhibit a destruction of symmetry and distortion of configuration. Various metals, including noble metals such as Pt, Ir, Ru, Au, and Ag [35,43–45], and non-noble metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, W, and Sn [36,46–50], can be utilized in DACs. For adjacent noble-metal-based DACs, Pt, Ru, and Rh elements have been widely reported due to their high activity [51–53]. For example, Zhou [52] employed an ice-seal-assisted photocatalytic reduction strategy to construct adjacent Pt-Ru monomers on N-rich vacancy g-C3N4 surfaces (Fig. 2 a). Elemental mapping analysis provides confirmation that Pt and Ru exhibit a comparable distribution pattern, indicating the presence of Pt-Ru monomers (Fig. 2b). N vacancy in the g-C3N4 can act as a region with an abundance of photogenerated electrons to reduce the adsorbed [PtCl6]2+ and Ru3+ ions. For CO oxidation, the first step O2 activation in homonuclear DACs structure (C-Ru-Ru-N and C-Pt-Pt-N) only occurs on one site. However, in C-Pt-Ru-N structure, O2 is adsorbed on Pt–O bond and Ru–O bond with enhanced O2 activation. Similarly, Pt-Ru dimer catalysts have been synthesized using an atomic layer deposition route [35]. Pt precursor is initially absorbed and then reacts with the N atoms on NCNTs to form Pt single atoms. With the addition of Ru precursors, the second noble metal Ru can attach on preliminary noble metal Pt, preferentially creating the bimetallic dimer configuration (Fig. 2c). Due to heavy Pt atoms and light Ru atoms that can be distinguished in aberration-corrected high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), the dimer-like Pt-Ru structure can be observed (Fig. 2d). Combining noble metals with non-noble metals to form metallic bonds can promote the thermodynamic stabilization and facilitate the stripping of individual metals from nanoparticles to form stable single atoms. Based on this, Zhou and co-workers [42] introduced a novel chemical facilitator to induce the formation of dual-metal (Rh–Fe) interbond (Fig. 2e). The Fe nanoparticles were converted to the corresponding single atoms at low temperatures. Even before pyrolysis, the presence of iron hinders the formation of Rh nanoparticles, and the formation of Rh–Fe bonds facilitates the stripping of bonded iron atoms from the metal nanoparticles. This dual metal interbond can snip the bonded metal atom from nanoparticles via enhancing thermodynamic stability. The feature of “hetero-pair” atoms can be confirmed in HAADF-STEM (Fig. 2f and g), indicating the formation of Rh–Fe interbonds. According to the results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Mössbauer spectroscopy in Fig. 2(h), Rh3+ can stabilize the atomic Fe-N4 unit and promote the formation of dual metal site. For non-noble metal adjacent DAC, the d-electron rich nature of transition metal center allows for flexible modulation of the electron structure through d-band coordination. This coordination can effectively lower energy barriers in catalytic processes. Wang et al. [33] achieved the synthesis of hollow carbon-derived materials containing (Fe, Co)/N-C dual metal sites through precise control of the bonding between the host Co nodes and guest Fe ions (Fig. 2i). From the Mössbauer spectroscopy in Fig. 2(j), the presence of multiple singlet iron species in (Fe,Co)/N-C confirms the existence of Fe-Co interaction. The precise coordination environment of Fe-Co dual metal sites can also be analyzed through the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) (Fig. 2k) and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) measurements (Fig. 2l). 2.1.2 Bridged configuration In heteronuclear bridged DACs, two different metal atoms are connected by bridged non-metallic atoms such as O, N, S, etc. When supported on various carriers like pristine carbon, carbon with heteroatom doping, and carbon nitride, heteronuclear DACs display diverse bonding configurations, such as M1-X-M2 (X = N, O, S, etc.). By linking noble metals and non-noble metals through heteroatomic bridges, the electronic configuration can be effectively optimized, leading to improved catalytic activity. As an illustration, Cheng et al. [54] doped transition metal Co and noble metal Ru into porous carbon nitride polymers through a self-seeded process to form Co-N4/Ru-N4 coordination (Fig. 3 a). The work function of Co-N4/Ru-N4 is higher than that of single site Co-N4 and Ru-N4 in Fig. 3(b), showing that electrons prefer to bind with the dual metal sites and promote efficient carrier transfer. Liu et al. [55] used a fine-grained “encapsulation-substitution” strategy to anchor the noble metal Ru and the transition metals Co, Fe, and Ni to form pairs of metal sites in N-doped carbon. In Fig. 3(c), the noble metal Ru and the transition metal are connected by a nitrogen bridge. The atomic spacing of Ru and Co was determined by statistical analysis (Fig. 3d), indicating that most of the metal atoms are paired as bridged configuration. The development of non-noble metal bridged DACs as alternatives to overcome the limitations of noble metals can also hold significant implications for future advancements. For example, Yang et al. [49] successfully incorporated Mn-N units into a conventional Fe/N-C configuration. They developed a bimetallic catalyst, Fe,Mn/N-C, through pre-polymerization and pyrolysis processes that resulted in atomic dispersion Fe and Mn on the carbon support (Fig. 3e). Multiple distinct dual spot-pairs with high intensity can be observed, indicating the presence of both Fe and Mn elements in the Fe,Mn/N-C catalyst. This coexistence of Fe and Mn is further confirmed by the electron energy loss spectrum (EELS) (Fig. 3f). The Fe K-edge XANES spectra obtained from simulations, along with the calculated Fe,Mn-N6 model configuration, demonstrate a remarkable correlation with the experimental spectra. This agreement strongly suggests that the Fe and Mn atoms are interconnected via nitrogen atoms and firmly attached to graphene nanosheets. Oxygen atoms of metal oxide (TiO2, CeO2, and CuO) have also been proven to possess the capability to anchor dual-metal sites. Mo and Ir dual atoms are attached on TiO2 to form Ir1Mo1/TiO2, and the presence of an Ir–O–Mo bond between randomly distributed Ir and Mo atoms can be inferred from the lower oxidation state of Ir and the higher oxidation state of Mo [44]. The strong bonding between surface lattice oxygen atoms and metal atoms provides stability to the guest cations [56]. For instance, Wang and co-workers [57] used a random high loading density deposition process to construct a containing partially non-bonding Co-O-Pt dimers coordinated by oxygen. The high-density Pt and Co dual atom sites, randomly anchored to the TiO2 substrate, form Co-Pt dual atom sites (Fig. 3g), and the lattice oxygen on the TiO2 serves as an oxygen bridge connecting Pt and Co (Fig. 3h). Moreover, Shi et al. [58] prepared Zn-Sn/CuO through a simple hydrothermal approach followed by wet impregnation (Fig. 3i), where incorporating single atom Sn into the CuO catalyst lattice results in the generation of Cu vacancy sites. These Cu vacancy sites are well-suited for capturing and stabilizing single-site Zn atoms. The HAADF-STEM characterization combined with energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis (Fig. 3j) provides further evidence of the presence of Zn, Sn, O, and Cu atoms in the Zn-Sn/Cu catalyst. In addition, MOF/ZIF can also be used as metal carriers to form DACs. For example, Zhang et al. [59] finely tuned the structure of NiN3@CoN3-NC by adjusting the Zn content and pyrolysis temperature of the precursor Zn/Co/Ni-zeolite imidazolate frameworks (Zn/Co/Ni-ZIFs). This work demonstrates the great potential of DACs as efficient CO2RR catalysts and provides a useful strategy for designing heteronuclear DACs. In addition to N and O bridges, S atom is often used as bridges connecting two metal atoms. For example, Xie et al. [60] employed a bi-functional ligand-assisted approach to regulate the presence of Fe and Zn atom pairs on carbon derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) (Fig. 3k). The EXAFS spectral fitting of Fe in Fe-Zn@SNC confirms the atomic dispersion and pairing of Fe and Zn, forming the FeN3-S-ZnN3 structure (Fig. 3l). 2.1.3 Separated configuration In addition to DACs with bonding interaction, heteronuclear DACs with separated sites also have excellent electrocatalytic properties. They exhibit ordered or disordered structural distributions through in-plane and spatial arrangement. Unlike single-atom catalysts, the separated configuration of DACs exhibits long-range interactions between different active sites. This catalytic system enables efficient and continuous catalysis for complex sequential reactions [61,62]. Space-continuous conductive networks are ideal for energy storage and conversion due to extensive carbon networks with layered pores and atomically dispersed metal sites (ADMS). For these reasons, Zhao et al. [63] used high-energy MOFs to fabricate submillimeter-scale carbon networks with layered porosity and ADMS. The HAADF-STEM shows separated bright spots, indicating the presence of Fe and Co ADMSs (Fig. 4 a–d). Conventional SACs often exhibit limited catalytic activity restricted to a single chemical reaction due to the inherent properties of individual metal species and the simplicity of their coordination configuration. However, it has been suggested that composite dual-atom sites with diverse spatial arrangements can exhibit remarkable multifunctional catalytic activity simultaneously. For instance, Chen et al. [64] synthesized the hollow graphene with various single-atom modifications on the separated side by assigning Ni and Fe single atoms located on both the inner and outer walls of hollow graphene nanorods, respectively. The quantitative parameters of the synthesized single-atom catalysts were determined by the application of the least-squares EXAFS fitting method. The results obtained indicate that the Ni and Fe sites exhibit tetra-coordination with nitrogen ligands (Fig. 4e–h). Among them, the external Fe-N4 site of GHSs has excellent ORR performance, while the external Ni-N4 site contributes to OER performance (Fig. 4i–l). The synergistic effect of the two metals results in excellent electrocatalytic selectivity and multi-functionality. 2.2 Homonuclear DACs 2.2.1 Adjacent configuration In homonuclear DACs, the different configurations can significantly change the electronic structure and chemical state by redistributing electrons between nearby individual active centers. The configurations of homonuclear DACs can be broadly classified into two types: adjacent configuration and bridged configuration. In recent years, homonuclear adjacent noble metal-based DACs have been intensively reported due to their excellent catalytic activity [43,65,66]. For example, Zhang et al. [65] reported an anion substitution deposition-precipitation method to synthesize Pd2 DAC with excellent CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) activity, where Pd and Pd were directly linked by metal bonding and loaded on acetylene black. Besides, Li et al. [43] reported diatomic Ag2/graphene DACs with a well-defined AgN3-AgN3 active site (Fig. 5 a). The EXAFS fitting exhibits that the two Ag atoms are directly connected (Fig. 5b), indicating that Ag atoms exist as dual atom. Nevertheless, the high cost and limited availability of noble metals have impeded wider application in industries. Transition metals-based DACs have been gradually investigated due to their shared advantages of affordability and abundance. For instance, Wang and co-workers [67] developed CoDACs by pyrolyzing supramolecular precursors and it exhibited an excellent photocatalytic CO2RR activity (Fig. 5c). According to Wavelet transforms of k 3 weighted EXAFS results (Fig. 5d), the Co atoms in CoDACs exhibit a Co-N coordination and a distinct Co-Co interaction, indicating that the Co atoms are directly connected. 2.2.2 Bridged configuration Homonuclear bridged configurations are the indirect coordination of two identical atoms through a bridge atom (e.g., N, S, or O). The varied coordination configuration can cause the redistribution of electron density in the metal active sites, resulting in different reaction mechanisms. Similarly, bridge-structured noble-metal DACs have attracted much attention for their excellent catalysis [68,69]. Yan and co-workers [69] deposited Pt2 dimers on graphene by a simpler atomic layer deposition method, in which one Pt atom was first deposited on graphene and then indirectly bond with another Pt atoms by a bridged oxygen atom (Fig. 5e). The statistical analysis displayed the longer Pt–Pt distance in Pt2 dimers than that in Pt bulk, which indicates that the Pt2 dimers are connected to oxygen atoms (Fig. 5f). Furthermore, non-noble metals such as Fe, Co, and Ni have been much reported in homonuclear bridged configurations [30,34,70–72], and the modulation of the electronic structure through bridge-connected has been applied in electrocatalysis. For instance, Zhang and co-workers [73] reported a planar-like Fe2N6 structure by thermally coupling FeN4 sites on a highly graphitized carbon substrate (Fig. 5g). In addition, the planar Fe2N6 structure exhibits a higher coordination number of Fe-Fe compared to separated FeN4 sites (Fig. 5h). The Fe-Fe coordination number in the Fe2N6 configuration approaches 1, indicating that the majority of the Fe atoms form dimers by bridging with another Fe atom through N. In homonuclear DACs, two different metal atoms can be loaded onto the carrier by direct linkage, indirect linkage through bridged atoms, and dispersion of independent atoms. In heteronuclear DACs, two identical metal atoms can be connected directly and indirectly by bridged atoms. These dual-atom geometrical configurations can be demonstrated by basic characterization tools such as HAADF-STEM, EXAFS, XANES, etc. In the future, a combination of more characterization techniques will be needed to accurately determine the configuration of DACs. 2.3 Synthesis methods and characterization techniques for DACs DACs are synthesized by a variety of methods, among which the wet chemical method is ideal for the synthesis of DACs due to its simplicity of operation. Among them, the typical strategies for preparing DACs include high temperature treatment [49], atomic layer deposition [35], ZIF/MOF method [60], and so on. In addition, the introduction of high-throughput screening and machine learning to guide the preparation of novel catalysts is a major trend in future development. This enables the efficient selection of highly active and stable DACs. After the preparation of the DACs, many of the necessary material characterization techniques are required to underpin them to determine the engineered structure of the DACs, as well as to study the intrinsic atomic and electronic structure and the relationship between the structure and the catalyst performance. Typical characterization techniques include HAADF-STEM, XANES, EXAFS, and so on. In cases where there is a substantial difference in atomic weights between metal combinations, like precious and non-precious metal pairs, the diatomic configuration can be confirmed by visually detecting two distinct bright atoms using HAADF-STEM. As a result of the noticeable weight contrast between heavy Pt atoms and light Ru atoms, the dimer-like Pt-Ru structure can be visualized using aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM [35]. Nevertheless, conclusions cannot be directly inferred through HAADF-STEM for some adjacent transition metal elements. In these situations, XANES and EXAFS can be utilized to determine the oxidation states of atoms, d-band characteristics, coordination charge, as well as orbital hybridization, coordination number, and symmetry, which collectively serve as evidence for the diatomic configuration. 3 Mechanism of metal-metal interactions in DACs The interaction of the two metals in DACs determines its catalytic mechanism, and therefore it is of great significance to investigate the metal-metal interactions for the future directed synthesis of DACs with specific catalytic effects. 3.1 Mechanism of metal-metal interactions in homonuclear DACs Metal-metal interactions in DACs can be mediated by the redistribution of electrons between adjacent separate active centers, and it is this redistribution of electrons that results in DACs with different types of metal atoms displaying unique atomic structures, coordination environments, and chemical states [74,75]. Among them, the metal-metal interactions of homonuclear DACs have been extensively studied, and the interaction between two identical metals can modulate the adsorption and desorption of intermediates, accelerating the complex catalytic reactions with a wide range of reaction intermediates. Recently, Chen et al. [76] synthesized P-doped carbon materials with W-W dual-atom sites (W-ACs) by anchoring W single atoms (W-SAs) as the catalyst materials for HER (Fig. 6 a). In order to elucidate the mechanism of the W-ACs acting as catalysts for the alkaline HER process, quasi in situ alkaline HER assessments were carried out by the analysis chamber of the near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (NAP-XPS) system, which monitored the desorption and adsorption of the OH* and H* intermediates in the HER process (Fig. 6b and c). The core-level XPS spectra analysis reveals that the W–O signal significantly increases in the W-ACs catalyst, indicating the preferential adsorption of the OH* intermediate on the W atom. When the negative potential is increased from −0.02 to −0.06 V, the signal intensity corresponding to the W–O bond is decreased. This suggests that OH* can be readily removed from the W center into the electrolyte at low potentials. In addition, the valence states of W-ACs subjected to various potentials exhibited consistent alterations, with many adsorbed H2O*, H*, and OH* intermediates covering the catalyst surface. During alkaline HER, the adsorbed hydrogen species (H2O* and H*) act as electron acceptors (Fig. 6c). Furthermore, the detachment of OH* intermediates is primarily attributed to the Coulombic effect. Therefore, the fast charge transfer to induce detachment behavior of H* intermediates should be attributed to the action of W-W homonuclear bimetallic bonds. In order to justify the mechanism of W–W bonding, local density of states calculations is able to explore the interactions between W and H atoms. In Fig. 6(d), the adsorbed H atoms exhibit suitable interaction strengths with W in W-ACs, and there are three hybridization peaks located at energy levels near the Fermi energy level, indicating that the strong W-H interactions have been weakened, thereby favoring the desorption of H* from the surface of W-ACs in the HER process. For some homonuclear DACs, constructing dual-atom sites and optimizing their catalytic microenvironment play a crucial role in boosting the catalytic activity of DACs. Hao et al. [77] reported a carbon-rich material with dual atom Ni sites (Ni2NC) (Fig. 6e). To investigate the active sites in Ni2NC for CO2RR, the first derivative of XANES in Fig. 6(f) shows a slight decrease in the oxidation state of Ni during CO2RR due to the charge transfer from the active site to the reactants and intermediates. These results suggest that Ni diatomic sites spontaneously adsorb hydroxide ions upon application of the potential, thus changing the microenvironment around the Ni active site. The analysis of the XANES spectra of Ni2NC yielded that the experimental XANES spectra during the CO2RR process are in good agreement with the theoretical XANES spectra described by the theoretical model (Fig. 6g). The relationship between the kinetic energy barriers of the different steps on the different active sites is presented in Fig. 6(h), which shows that the OHad-induced increase in the charge of the central Ni site will promote the activation of CO2, and result in a lower energy of *COOH formation on the OHad Ni site than on the OHad-free Ni site. Therefore, the introduction of OHad enhances the adsorption of intermediates and creates an electron-rich microenvironment in the active site, thus optimizing the CO2RR process. 3.2 Mechanism of metal-metal interactions in heteronuclear DACs Compared with homonuclear DACs, heteronuclear DACs composed of metal atoms with two different electronic configurations can effectively regulate the reaction intermediates through different metal bonds. Compared to the distance effect between active sites of single-atom catalysts, the interaction between adjacent atoms in DACs can result in charge redistribution and optimization of the d-band center, thereby affecting the electronic structure through interaction between spatially neighboring atoms. DACs with metal-metal can not only take advantage of single-atom sites but also exhibit synergistic effects between different metal sites [19,78]. For complex catalytic reactions, heteronuclear DACs can enhance catalytic activity and stability by providing different intermediate adsorption configurations at the main catalytic center through the regulating effect of secondary metals. For instance, Zhu and co-workers [79] successfully synthesized a quasi-covalently coupled Ni-Cu DACs with precisely controlled Ni 3d electronic configuration using dual metallic NiZn zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (Fig. 6i). To better understand the dynamics of the Ni atomic valence state during CO2RR, the EXAFS detection of the in-situ Ni K-edge was used. The valence state of Ni in Ni-N-C gradually increases at high potentials, and the excessively reduced Ni element exhibits lower activity in CO2RR. In contrast, the Ni atomic valence state in Ni/Cu-N-C shows a positive shift in the absorption energy of the K-edge XANES spectra of Ni because of the charge transfer from Ni to *CO. Meanwhile, the Ni K-edge of Ni/Cu-N-C shifts to a low-energy direction as the voltage is increased, which suggests that Ni reverts to the low oxidation state. The results suggest that the inclusion of Cu not only enhances the conversion of CO2-CO but also provides protection to Ni against excessive reduction. As a result, the Ni sites exhibit improved activity and stability. Moreover, the formation of Ni-Cu atom pairs results in an upward shift of the d-band center, suggesting an enhanced binding affinity of the intermediate at the NiCuN6 site (Fig. 6l). Thus, the doping of Cu as a guest metal causes a positive change in the energy level of the Ni atom 3d orbitals towards the Fermi energy level. This shift accelerates the generation of the crucial intermediate *COOH and enhances the rate of CO2RR. Different metal elements can modulate the reaction selectivity and activity of DACs. In this regard, Fan et al. [78] employed pyrolyzing zeolitic imidazolate frameworks to synthesize an atomically distributed In-Ni DACs (named as InNi DS/NC) (Fig. 6m). To track the intermediates during the electrocatalytic process, in situ attenuated total reflectance surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) experiments were conducted (Fig. 6n). With decreasing potentials, the intensity of the CO stretching peak of the *COOH intermediate at 1400 cm−1 gradually increased, suggesting that the extent of surface occupancy *COOH on the surface of the electrodes was increased. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to explore the relationship between configuration and properties. The charge density difference between Ni and In atoms in the InNi DS/NC underwent a change, suggesting the presence of electronic interactions between the oxygen bridges and the home of the InNi double site (Fig. 6o). Furthermore, the selectivity of InNi DS/NC towards CO2RR was evaluated by calculating the discrepancy in the limiting potentials between CO generation and H2 evolution. A greater positive difference indicates a higher CO selectivity (Fig. 6p). Overall, the interaction between the two metals in homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs plays a crucial role in the catalytic mechanism. Studying the relationship between atomic configurations and electronic effects in DACs is crucial for understanding catalytic mechanisms and designing efficient catalysts. It provides valuable guidance for both theoretical and experimental research in the field of catalysis. 4 DACs for electrocatalytic applications Electrocatalysis plays a vital role in energy conversion processes. Recently, the field of electrocatalysis has witnessed significant interest in the application of DACs, which have shown promising performance in various catalytic reactions. DACs can be applied to a variety of catalytic types, such as ORR, OER, HER, and more. The use of DACs in these catalytic processes enables the efficient conversion of chemical energy into electrical energy, which is essential for various applications including metal-air batteries. These advancements in energy storage and conversion hold significant promise for the future of sustainable energy systems. 4.1 Oxygen reduction reaction O2 molecules can be electrocatalytically reduced to H2O in acid or OH− in alkaline conditions [80–82]. Searching high performance 4e− ORR plays a pivotal role in numerous energy conversion devices, including proton exchange membrane fuel cells and regenerative metal-air batteries. As known, Pt-based nanomaterials exhibit excellent catalytic activity for ORR, while isolated atomic Pt sites may exhibit reduced selectivity due to the sluggish kinetics for breaking O–O bond [83,84]. Constructing Pt metal atom pairs can enhance the selectivity and activity of DACs catalysts toward 4e− pathway. For example, Zhang et al. [85] reported an atomic Pt-based DACs catalysts with atomic Co-Pt pairs anchored on defective N-doped graphene and exhibited high selectivity to 4e− ORR pathway in alkaline conditions. The synergistic interaction between atomic Pt and Co modifies the electronic configuration of the metal atoms and influences the charge distribution. In view of the scarcity of Pt metal catalysts, a further step has been taken to minimize the loading of Pt in Pt-based DACs. Gao and co-workers [86] constructed a single-atom Pt-Fe pair (denoted as Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3) with ultra-low Pt loading on the crystalline surface of α-Fe2O3, where the ratio of Pt/Fe atoms is about 1/1500. Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3 achieved excellent ORR catalytic performance in alkaline condition, with an outstanding onset potential despite the low Pt loading (Fig. 7 a). Therefore, the excellent mass activity of Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3 at 0.95 V provides evidence of its potential for practical electrocatalytic applications (Fig. 7b). Furthermore, Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3 was further applied to zinc-air batteries to demonstrate its potential in practical energy conversion devices, which considering practical industrial applications. The peak power density of the zinc-air battery with Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3 as cathode exceeds the performance of 20% Pt/C (Fig. 7c). It is shown that this work opens an avenue for the vigorous development of efficient electrocatalysts for energy storage and conversion systems. In addition to lowing the loading of noble Pt-based catalysts, developing cost-effective transition metal-based DACs catalysts is also available [87]. For example, Wu and co-workers [88] bridged Fe and Co atoms by N and S heteroatoms to form FeN4S1/CoN4S1 configuration. The FeCo-DACs exhibit lower half-wave potential and higher diffusion current density than referred Fe-NSC and Co-NSC catalysts (Fig. 7d). Besides, in-situ Raman revealed that Fe-Co DACs has no obvious change after ORR cycles, indicating its high structural configuration of FeN4S1/CoN4S1 (Fig. 7e and f). To sum up, the dual-atomic sites can synergistically tailor the electronic structure to optimize the adsorption energy of OOH* and OH*, promote the activation of O–O bond, and enhance the charge transfer for excellent electrocatalytic ORR activity. In addition, the Zn-air battery was constructed with FeCo-NSC as the cathode and a Zn plate as the anode. The experimental findings demonstrated that the peak power density of the Zn-air battery utilizing FeCo-NSC was 1.5 times greater compared to the battery employing Pt/C as the catalyst (Fig. 7g–i). 4.2 Oxygen evolution reaction The OER has garnered significant attention due to its critical role in energy conversion and storage devices, such as metal-air batteries and water-splitting electrolyzers [71,89,90]. However, the inherently sluggish reaction dynamics in the 4e− transfer progress greatly limits its vigorous development [91]. Currently, Ru/Ir-based catalysts have been recognized as effective catalysts for OER, while the relatively poor stability and high cost of Ru/Ir resources limit their large-scale applications [92–94]. Therefore, the atomic-scale design of DACs is anticipated to minimize the utilization of costly Ru/Ir metals and enhance the intrinsic activity of the catalytic sites. For example, Rong and co-workers [95] introduced Co into Ru-N4 configuration to regulate the affinity of intermediate species on the Ru surface. Due to the electron redistribution around the Ru-N4 active sites induced by Co-N4, the corrosion resistance of Ru-Co DACs can be improved during both acid and alkaline electrolysis (Fig. 8 a). N atoms of Co-N4 sites serve as electron reservoirs, donating additional electrons to the Ru-N4 sites. This electron transfer mechanism effectively enhances the resistance of Ru-N4 active sites to over-oxidation and corrosion. Transition metal catalysts for OER have been vigorously developed for cost-saving purposes, in which surface atomic engineering has emerged as a promising approach to enhance the activity and stability of transition metal-based electrocatalysts for OER. Pei and co-workers [96] designed hollow prisms Ni-Co DACs with Ni and Co embedded on N-doped carbon (a-NiCo/NC). Compared with single-metal-site and nanoparticle catalysts, a-NiCo/NC material demonstrates the lowest onset overpotential (Fig. 8b) and excellent durability after a long-term operation (Fig. 8c). Theoretically, the rate-determining step of single-metal-site catalysts is the formation of *O, but the rate-determining step of a-NiCo/NC changes to the formation of *OOH (Fig. 8d). The strong electronic coupling between Ni and Co atoms of a-NiCo/NC can upshift the d-band centers to Fermi level (Fig. 8e and f), leading more antibonding states and obtaining different abilities to bind with reactive intermediates. Therefore, the combined effect of neighboring Ni-Co dual metal centers can optimize the adsorption and desorption characteristics, leading to a reduction in overall reaction barriers [96–98]. In addition, the transition metals have different catalytic effects in combination with each other, considering that the interaction between Fe and Ni atoms can enhance the activity of OER. Luo et al. [99] used the introduction of Fe atoms to modify the catalytic behavior of single atom Ni catalysts, resulting in synergistic FeNi DACs with excellent OER performance (Fig. 8g). The OER performance of FeNi DACs was much better than that of Fe SACs, Ni SACs, and commercial Pt/C catalysts. By assembling the FeNi DACs in the anode of zinc-air batteries, good charging and discharging activities (Fig. 8h) and stability were demonstrated (Fig. 8i). In conclusion, the metallic bond of adjacent metals such as Ni–Co, Fe–Ni, and Fe–Co can induce the strong electronic coupling and adjustable d-band centers, which may result in the increased positive charge near the active sites and further enhance the adsorption of intermediate species [100–102]. 4.3 Hydrogen evolution reaction HER is a two-electron transfer reaction and occurs at the cathode of water splitting reaction (2H+ + 2e−→ H2). The current effective HER catalysts are mainly noble-metal (Pt/Ru/Ir)-based nanoparticles [103–107]. Notably, through regulating the electron interaction between two different single atom, heteronuclear DACs can accelerate HER by efficiently providing dual-sites for H* and/or OH* intermediates [95]. Liu and co-workers [108] found Pt-Ru bridged dimer configuration supported on defective and nitrogen-doped graphene with optimal adsorption energetics of OH* and small kinetic barriers of water dissociation. Zhao and co-workers [51] demonstrated that the Ru atom releases additional free electrons to the Pt atom through the formation of adjacent Pt-Ru configuration. Through the modulation of electron redistribution by Ru atoms, the Pt atoms serving as active sites exhibit a high affinity for adsorbing intermediates. Besides, Zhang and co-workers [35] successfully attached the second metal (Ru) on the preliminary one (Pt) to form the adjacent Pt-Ru dimer structure on carbon nanotube. Due to the existence of dimer structure, Pt-Ru DAC shows higher HER activity (Fig. 9 a) and stability (Fig. 9b). Besides, with the augmentation of H adsorption, the Pt and Ru will result in more unoccupied states and be changed from metal to semiconductor, leading hydrogen atom easily to be detached. The electronic configuration of Pt-Ru dimer plays a vital role in modulating the interaction between intermediates H and active sites Ru atom, thus exhibiting the low ΔG H (Fig. 9c). In addition, local electric fields with asymmetry can modulate the adsorption configuration of catalytic intermediates, optimizing adsorption and desorption and thus improving the catalytic activity of DACs. For example, Cai et al. [109] used IrRu heteronuclear DACs to design an atomically asymmetric local electric field to regulate the adsorption configuration and orientation of its structural H2O to optimize the dissociation process. IrRu heteronuclear DACs had the highest alkaline HER activity, with overpotentials and HER kinetic energy barrier much lower than reference samples (Fig. 9d and e). To evaluate the practical application of IrRu DACs, membrane electrode assembly tests were performed. The results show that IrRu DACs have excellent practical value (Fig. 9f). Considerable attention has been dedicated to investigating economical, efficient, and long-lasting alternatives for HER catalysts, aiming to replace Pt/Ru-based materials. For this reason, Yang and co-workers [36] bridged W and Mo through oxygen atom to obtain W-O-Mo heterodimer configuration. The bridged dimer configuration, characterized by strong covalent interactions, exhibits excellent stability and catalytic performance for pH-universal HER. In acid conditions, W1Mo1-NG shows excellent catalytic activity and gives a starting potential close to zero (Fig. 9g), which is better than that of homonuclear dual metal Mo2-NG and W2-NG. The O-bridging in the W-O-Mo configuration shows optimal ΔG H in electrocatalytic HER (Fig. 9h). Additionally, the stability and durability of W1Mo1-NG were further analyzed. Under acidic and alkaline conditions, the polarization curves of the HER remained essentially unchanged after over fifty thousand cycles. This excellent stability can be attributed to the robust W-O-Mo-O-C structure. Electrons are delocalized in W1Mo1-NG system, indicating that the O-coordinated W-Mo heterodimer exhibits a strong covalent nature with weak ionic property (Fig. 9i). 4.4 Other catalysis DACs also exhibited outstanding catalytic performances in the diverse array of reactions including CO2RR, nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), and so on [30,38,59,110,111]. The CO2RR holds tremendous importance in mitigating CO2 emissions and generating value-added chemicals, leading to both economic and environmental advantages [112]. However, the practical application of this promising technology has faced significant challenges due to the chemical inertness of CO2 and competition with CO2RR and HER, resulting in low activity and selectivity. Recently, the attention has been focused on homonuclear DACs for their ability to adsorb CO2 and stabilize intermediates [113]. Meanwhile, heteronuclear DACs with complementary functionalities and synergistic effects are favorable for CO2RR. Zeng and co-workers [38] anchored Ni-Fe diatomic pairs on N-doped graphene for CO2-to-CO conversion. NiFe-DACs produced the highest current density and the lowest onset potential. The d band center of Fe in Ni-Fe DACs is lower than that in Fe-SAC due to the decrease energy levels of antibonding states, further resulting in faster CO desorption. Moreover, the electrons are transferred from Fe to coordinating N, leading to a higher oxidation state of Fe center to promote CO2 activation. DACs have also been intensively studied as promising catalysts for NRR [30,114–116]. For example, Guo et al. [30] conducted theoretical calculations to explore the potential of metal dimers on two-dimensional extended phthalocyanines for NRR under acidic conditions. The work demonstrates the wide applicability and potential of these catalysts for efficient NRR, offering promising solutions for sustainable ammonia production and addressing global nitrogen fixation challenges. Meanwhile, the application of DACs in HOR catalysis is a popular and active research field [110,117]. Taking Ru-Ni DACs as an example, Han et al. [110] synthesized Ru-Ni DACs loaded on N-doped porous carbon (RuNi/NC), which exhibited excellent alkaline HOR activity and CO tolerance. DACs show great potential to improve the kinetics and performance of various electrocatalysis, laying the foundation for the advancement of more efficient and sustainable energy conversion technologies. DACs also have many applications in sulfur reduction reactions (SRR) [118–121]. For example, Wu et al. [118] synthesized a dual-atom Zn-Co catalyst loaded on a double-shell nitrogen-doped carbon material (Zn-Co SA@DNC) to achieve efficient catalysis of lithium polysulfides. This work provides insight into the catalytic mechanism of DACs for accelerating sulfur conversion in lithium polysulfides. Although DACs play an important role in electrocatalysis, their catalytic selectivity and stability are not yet satisfactory enough to hinder the industrialization of electrocatalysis for large-scale applications. The search for the stability of DACs needs to focus on strengthening the bonding strength between the metal and the metal carrier, and it is then necessary to devise a screening method for DACs to ensure that the DACs have considerable stability in both acidic and alkaline environments. So far, some strategies have been explored to improve the stability of DACs, including introduction of heteroatom metals, enhancement of metal-support interaction and modulation of local environment. For example, Sun et al. [122] used DFT and machine learning techniques for theoretical calculations, proposing that introducing selected heteroatom metals into transition metals can optimize stability and electroactivity. Besides, Fu et al. [44] synthesized Ir1Mo1/TiO2 by depositing bimetallic Mo and Ir onto TiO2, where the random distribution of Ir and Mo atoms leads to the formation of Ir–O–Mo bonds. The strong interaction between the surface lattice oxygen atoms and metal atoms greatly improves the stability of the catalyst. Hao et al. [77] presented a carbon-rich material containing dual Ni atom sites and showed that enhancing stability could be achieved by altering the microenvironment surrounding the active nickel site. Therefore, a more in-depth exploration of the relationship between the configuration and performance of DACs is still needed in the future. 5 Conclusions and perspectives In this review, the latest developments in the configuration, mechanism, and various catalytic performances of DACs are summarized. Based on the geometrical configuration of the active sites in various homonuclear/heteronuclear DACs, DACs are classified into three categories: adjacent, bridged, and separated configurations. The relationship between configuration and mechanism reveals that the catalytic mechanisms of homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs are distinct. These two configurations of DACs exhibit excellent performance in various electrocatalytic processes, such as HER, OER, ORR, and other catalysis. This understanding opens new avenues for the future design principles of DACs. Although DACs have significant advantages over SACs in terms of catalytic activity, their development also faces some challenges. For instance, DACs may undergo agglomeration during the synthesis process, which poses challenges in achieving catalysts with high metal loading and uniform dispersion. The accurate identification and characterization of active sites in DACs also remains ongoing challenges. Below, some of the challenges faced by the field are highlighted, and potential research directions that are expected to be well-developed in the future are outlined. (1) Difficulty in achieving precise modulation of DACs configurations. During the synthesis of DACs, the formation of mononuclear sites is unavoidable. This can occur when bimetallic dimers, which are desired for the synergistic effect, undergo reduction or decomposition during the synthesis process. While DACs offer the advantage of increased active site loading compared to SACs, it is worth noting that excessive metal loading can result in the clustering of active sites, leading to a loss of catalytic performance. Therefore, future accurate modulation for DACs configurations may need to be achieved by properly controlling and optimizing the amount of metal loading. (2) Developing advanced characterization techniques for DACs. There is an urgent need to identify and detect catalytic reaction processes using advanced characterization techniques. By employing a range of characterization methods to study the dynamics of catalytic reaction intermediates, researchers can gain a better understanding of the electrocatalytic mechanisms of these catalysts. Existing characterization techniques, such as HAADF-STEM, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), and XAFS, have demonstrated the capability to detect specific configurations of materials. Therefore, in order to gain a deeper understanding of DACs and its catalytic processes, it may be necessary to develop more accurate in situ characterization techniques to monitor the dynamic behavior of the dual-atom catalytic site. (3) Developing the commercialization potential of DACs. DACs have shown great application potentiality in metal-air batteries and fuel cells. However, the industrialization of DACs still faced some challenges such as high-power density and long-term stability. Meeting these requirements is crucial for the successful implementation of DACs on an industrial scale, as they need to maintain their catalytic activity without experiencing significant degradation or changes over extended periods. Therefore, more complex synthetic methods may be required to ensure strong interactions between the metal pair and the substrate, which helps to improve the stability of the DACs by reducing the surface free energy of the catalyst. In general, the development of DACs faces some challenges such as precise structural modulation, advanced characterization techniques, and industrialization. DACs offer a promising address for energy crisis and enable efficient energy conversion. Currently, DACs have achieved remarkable effects in the electrocatalytic processes mentioned above. DACs are expected to pave the way in the fields of other energy-related catalysis such as organic electrocatalytic and photocatalysis [123–127]. Electrocatalytic processes often contain multiple proton-coupled electron transfers, such as the aerobic oxidation of organic molecules [128]. This necessitates that the catalyst possess a large exposed surface area and high catalytic activity. With their flexible active sites and exceptional atom utilization efficiency, DACs demonstrate great promise in the realm of multi-electron electrocatalysis. Guðmundsson, J. Bäckvall, Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 60 (2021) 15686-15704. Tao Zhang received her B.S. degree in 2022 from Shenyang University of Chemical Technology, China. She is currently a postgraduate at Nanjing University of Science and Technology, China. Her research focuses on single-atom catalysts for electrocatalytic applications. Yifan Liu received his BSc degree in Chemical Engineering from Nanjing Tech University, China, in 2019. He is now pursuing his Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Professor Junwu Zhu and Pan Xiong in the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Nanjing University of Science and Technology, China. His research focuses on transition metal oxide nanomaterials and their intrinsic properties for electrocatalytic applications. Pan Xiong is a Professor at the Nanjing University of Science and Technology, China. He received his PhD degree in Materials Science and Engineering from the same university in 2015. He was a visiting PhD student at the University of Texas at Austin followed by working as a JSPS postdoctoral researcher at the National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS), Japan and then a research associate at the University of Technology Sydney, Australia. His research focuses on two-dimensional nanomaterials for energy conversion and storage applications. Junwu Zhu received his PhD degree in materials chemistry from the Nanjing University of Science and Technology in 2005. He is presently working as a professor at the same university. His main research interests are focused on the preparation and application of functional materials based on carbon and nanostructured composites.

coredata.dc:description: Geometrical configurations play a crucial role in dual-atom catalysts (DACs) for electrocatalytic applications. Significant progress has been made to design DACs electrocatalysts with various geometrical configurations, but in-depth understanding the relationship between geometrical configurations and metal-metal interaction mechanisms for designing targeted DACs is still required. In this review, the recent progress in engineering of geometrical configurations of DACs is systematically summarized. Based on the polarity of geometrical configuration, DACs can be classified into two different types that are homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs. Furthermore, with regard to the geometrical configurations of the active sites, homonuclear DACs are identified into adjacent and bridged configurations, and heteronuclear DACs can be classified into adjacent, bridged, and separated configurations. Subsequently, metal-metal interactions in DACs with different geometrical configurations are introduced. Additionally, the applications of DACs in different electrocatalytic reactions are discussed, including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and other catalysis. Finally, the future challenges and perspectives for advancements in DACs are highlighted. This review aims to provide inspiration for the design of highly efficient DACs towards energy related applications.
